abstract:
The Multiple Depot Ring-Star Problem (MDRSP) is an important combinatorial
optimization problem arising in the context of optical fiber network design,
resource allocation in monitoring applications, to name a few. In particular,
given a set of depots and a set of customers, it consists of designing a set of
simple cycles (rings), each of which passes through exactly one depot and
through some customers, and then assigning each non-visited customer to a depot
or a visited customer in some ring. The objective is to minimize the sum of the
total routing costs and total assignment costs. In this paper, we present a
mixed integer linear programming formulation for the MDRSP and propose valid
inequalities to strengthen the linear programming relaxation. Furthermore, we
do a complete polyhedral analysis and derive facet-inducing results for the
MDRSP. All these results are then used to develop a branch-and-cut algorithm to
obtain optimal solutions to the MDRSP. The performance of the branch-and-cut
algorithm is evaluated through extensive computational experiments on a several
classes of test instances.
